text: Okay, the tape is on. Would you give us some biographical data on how you grew up and how you got interested in writing science fiction. Well, I grew up in Kansas. Both of my parents teach. At least my mother used to and then she became a newspaper woman. So we, I grew up with words around the house, a lot. Oh, I was making up stories from, well, I guess I was four or five, the kind of thing where mother reads you the bedtime story and puts you to bed and nobody feels like going to sleep yet. So since I was too young to read, I hadn't discovered reading on the covers with flashlights yet, I made up stories until I was ready to go to sleep. And then I started writing them down when I learned to write. And about junior high school, I discovered science fiction. Up to then, it was cowboys and horses, with a lot of girls, I think. I discovered science fiction in junior high, and I don't know why it caught me the way it did. I kind of got away from it later and got strictly into mystery, and then came back to science fiction when I was in college. and I've been hooked on science fiction mysteries ever since. You probably noticed that a lot of the combination of the two in my work. Being a little Kansas girl did you ever read the Oz books? No, as a matter of fact I think aside from The Wizard of Oz I think I'd only seen I knew there were a number of others because I had some friends that had others but I'd never read them and I still haven't read them. The dedications to all five of the books that you have in print now are all to Pat. He must have influenced you a great deal. Could you give some background into that influence and how he helped you get where you are? When we got married, I was writing. We got married back in 66, and I think that Star Trek was either on the air, I think it was on the air at the time, and like a lot of people I got really hooked on Star Trek and was writing episodes for it, and I guess at that time we were just going together. At any rate, when we got married, I had stopped writing Star Trek and writing some stuff of my own and he got ignored somewhat because I was busy writing and he said as long as you are going to be doing that, why don't you try sending it out? He bugged me, bugged me until I finally started sending things out and once I got sent sending stuff out, of course I had lots of rejections. he was very good about letting me cry on his shoulder and also very candid about his opinion in on the various stories, some which led to grand battles, but he usually turned out to be right. So he was very influential in getting me writing and in getting me sending out and keeping me sending out. And then once the story started selling, and once I turned to novels, he was my critic and chief cheerleader. and I understand there are a lot of spouses that writers don't like to consult with their spouses very much because they're either too critical or they're not critical enough. But Pat is very objective and he's an excellent critic and he knows, he has a good feel for what is right and what's wrong with a story. And he has to hear everything I read chapter by chapter and all the revisions so he's very patient and long-suffering and he puts up with being ignored evening after evening so that I can write because I've got deadlines I have to meet. He understands that. He makes sure I don't kill myself. Well, he comes in and pulls the plug on the typewriter at 2 or 3 in the morning if I'm starting to pull an all-nighter to make sure I get to sleep because I do have a job to get to the next morning. So he's very important. He's, as I say, a chief critic and cheerleader. he's now also my business manager he handles the publicity he talks to the TV stations to get the interviews on TV to get autograph sessions set up he handles plane tickets and hotel reservations and all the business ends he's an attorney so he's an expert on copyright and he's starting to get seminars on copyright as a matter of fact and he handles all the taxes and all the business work So, it's kind of a partnership. I do the writing and get the publishing done. And he does all the work that keeps it going. According to the bios in the backs of some of the books, it also says that Pat introduced you to science fiction fandom and to science fiction conventions. Do you find these a great help to your writing? I've met a lot of writers at the science fiction conventions. I've just been doing short stories. and it was meeting the writers that got me started writing the novels because they were the ones who were saying, that's the only place you're going to make any money or make any kind of name for yourself. But short stories, you can't make any money in short stories. And, of course, some of the writers have become some of my dearest friends now. I really like talking about writing. So I love meeting fans who want to do nothing more than sit up all night and talk about science fiction and writing. and I really think that it helps because you meet people, and then you're a face to them, not just a name, and they'll read something that is written by someone they know, and then they can recommend it to friends, and I realize that only a very small percentage of the population is in fandom and attends a convention. If all the fans in the United States bought a book, it would be a failure. You have to have a lot more than that. But still, I think it helps. And you get used to talking to people and get used to going on TV shows. Pretty soon, I'm going to make some trips to the East Coast this year, and I hope soon to make some trips to the West Coast, which means I'll get autograph sessions at bookstores out there, which will get my name spread a little wider. So aside from being a lot of fun, I think that as far as a writing career goes, that going to the convention is very, it pays. You also work full-time, as I understand it. Would you describe what your real-world job is and also how you schedule your writing and your job so you can get both done? well the job is a regular 9 to 5 job as it happens I'm chief technologist in the department of radiology at the college of veterinary medicine I'm an x-ray technician for animals in what it amounts to I'm in charge of educating the vet students that is I'm in charge of them when they're in the department itself which is sort of a laboratory situation for them and I think It's a 9-to-5 job, and then I come home and write in the evening. I usually end up taking a notebook with notes on whatever the current work is to work with me, and there's a hiatus now and then. And when that happens, I can sit down and jot notes. I can't actually get any writing done. I've got too much to do, and there isn't enough of a long span of no work to get anything done. but a lot of times in the midst of purely physical activity or purely routine activity at work, something I've been having a problem with, for instance, or an idea for a revision or an idea of something to do in the chapter ahead will come up, and I can jot it down. I'm still working while I'm in the real world job because my subconscious is still grinding away of whatever the writing project is at home, And then I come home when I write in the evening and I'll write through on weekends, too. How do your colleagues and students at work take to your writing? What do they think about it? They're very tickled about it. I didn't know how administration and some of the doctors, the clinicians, would take to it because science fiction in many quarters thought of as a very lowbrow kind of writing. writing, but I find that they're very pleased about it when the dean of the vet school brings people to our hospital on a tour. He usually makes mention of the fact that I'm a public science fiction writer, and I've gotten a couple of attaboy kind of letters from the president of the university. And we have, of course, journalism students at the university, and I'm usually good for for about one appearance in the paper per semester, as one of the journalism students has to get his so many inches of copy in, and almost always one of them will appear. I'm pretty well publicized around campus, and I don't find them looking down on me because I'm being published in fiction and science fiction instead of in scientific journals, like most of them get published. So they take it very well and my boss is a real king. I usually turn in my convention schedule to him at the beginning of summer. He fits his vacations in between my convention schedule. And he lets me off almost any weekend I want during the year to go to conventions too. Our first exposure to you as a novelist was A Voice out of Rama. And that book seemed to set the tone for some of your subsequent works with the various elements in it. As you mentioned previously, it's got a bit of a mystery, although not quite as much as some of the other novels. How did you come to write this book? How long did the idea sit there percolating before it came out? I don't really know. I try to keep track of the process of creativity because it fascinates me. Also, because as a writer I'm asked so many questions about where ideas come from and how they develop that I keep trying to find out. I had a couple of writers who ganged up on me at some conventions convincing me that I really needed to write a novel. And I don't know, just these little bits and pieces just all came together. I keep telling people that creativity is a little bit like recombinant DNA. all the little everything you read and see and hear breaks up into component parts and proves around your subconscious until it reaches a critical mass that is also viable and then it rises to the surface and you start putting ideas around it because the idea that comes up is just the grain in the middle you have to add all the rest of it around but I had tried to do some Sherlock Holmes pastitions. And one of them was a reverse, where all the Holmes, Watson characters were females. And I had half invented a planet that had a matriarchy. So that got me started thinking about how a matriarchy would work, and why it would develop. And so I found myself working back for causes like that, And all of a sudden I had the society that I used then in Voice Out of Rama. And once I had the society, I just kind of sat down and thought, well, what kind of plot elements, what kind of conflicts can arise out of this society that would probably not arise out of any other? And who is the one that's going to be most affected by these? And so I came up with the plot that way, and I came up with my major character that way. After that, it was fun just building the planet and trying to make it as realistic and as logical as I could. Then the doppelganger gamut came along, and it seemed to be quite a change of pace since it was basically a police procedure science fiction novel. You seem to be very familiar with police procedure, with how partners have the interaction, that sort of thing? Is this something from your background or did you have to research this? I haven't had any practical experience in it. I did have a police officer come up to me at a science fiction convention once when I'd been reading a chapter of Doppelganger. And he asked me when I worked in law enforcement. But I've been interested in law enforcement for a long time. I noticed that the mysteries I always liked to read were the ones in which the police were the good guys. I was never particularly interested in the lone wolf private eye. I got listened to Dragnet on the radio and saw it on TV when I was pretty small, and I think maybe that's my first brush with police work, and I was just very interested in it. Joseph Wambau is one of my favorite authors, and I happened to know somebody, by the way, who gave him a copy of Doppelganger Gambit, and he told his friend that he really liked it a lot, which tickled me. Once I decided I wanted to write a mystery science fiction, I went ahead and did more research, and I've kept into it, and of course that book itself and others have brought me into contact with more police officers, and they've passed on a lot of material to me. And so, short of actually working in it myself, I have gotten very familiar with it. I suppose I keep reading about it, or writing about it, because it was interesting and because I've done so much research on it that it's a shame not to use the material. The key to that book for me was the characters, Jana Brill and Mama Maxwell. Were they based on people you'd known before, or what? No, they were based on nobody I know, except that I always pictured Mama Maxwell as looking like Luke Ossett Jr., which I was very surprised, then, to get the cover proof and find that the cover artist, Michael Herring, had also pictured him the same way and found a model that looked so much like the character that I'd pictured. It was wonderful. Somewhere in the beginning when I was putting the book together, which had started as a novelette, and I knew it couldn't be a novelette because here I was 15 pages into something and just barely starting it, I had decided I wanted to use a Lady Cop. So for contrast, I gave her a male partner and I can't remember why I decided to make him black it was one of these things that just kind of happened somebody later pointed out that I had my female character was the one that was working by the book and procedure and my male character was the one who was working on intuition which is an interesting reverse on the way people generally think of males and females and that just sort of happened the characters sort of balanced one another but a lot of the balance was unconscious on my part they were fun characters and I intend to work with them again. So we will see them again. Oh, yes. As soon as I can think of something more for them to get into. One of the other things that I really noticed in the book that made it that much more realistic was the slang. I'm particularly curious where the term Leos came from, a reference to the police officers. I would think I was seeing something about law enforcement officers one time and I noticed that it made Leo, And I thought, that's great, because it gave rise in my mind to all kinds of connotations, and I could see police officers enjoying being called Leos because of the lion, the fierce kind of association you get with it, and therefore calling police stations lion den. And someone who's likely to be picked up by the police is lion meat. I had a pejorative I had the street people calling them pussies when they weren't happy with them but my editor wouldn't let me keep the word in the book so I think it got changed to kitty a couple of times in the book and I illuminated it where possible because I really didn't like watered down I really did want to use pussy because it seemed to me like the normal way people would pick up and twist something when they wanted to make a derogatory term out of it I enjoy the slang. I enjoy trying to figure out where slang comes from and where it's going to go. And you may have noticed in a number of the books that I've played on slang, there's quite a bit of it in Deadly Silence. And I'm even having some alien slang in the current work I'm doing. Deadly Silence seemed, I took, to be in the same future history as the doppelganger gambit. They all are, as a matter of fact, except monitor. That was in a different one. And there you went a little bit into the etymology of the word cop. I didn't realize that's where it came from until I read it in that book. There are several possibilities. They usually teach a little bit of that in police history. When they're teaching in police academies, One thought it meant constable on patrol, and sometimes it said, well, it comes from the copper buttons that they used to wear. And the exact origin of the word isn't known. But it's interesting to me to stumble across the term conservator of peace way back in early England. And it seems to me that an alien who was reading Earth's history and having come across the word cop, referring to police officers, and the earlier conservative of peace, conservator of peace, might connect the two. I found it interesting that the duties of the cops, you did call them cops from then on, from chapter 2 or whatever, for the rest of the book, because of the connotations of Leos. I found it interesting that their first priority was to the victim, and then, lo and behold, later on, they have to defend the perpetrator. Where did you come up with these seemingly novel ideas? They kind of grew out of the society of the Aragara because the primary objective of the police there was, of course, to restore peace, to be peace officers. and of course when anything happened that was distressful to the Aragara it was painful to everybody around them. So the first duty then was to the victim to help them understand what had happened to them. I suppose it reflects a little bit of a reaction to some of the things that I've seen in our own culture where the victim suffers a lot because everybody's so interested in catching the guy who did it a lot of times they're not paying too much attention to the victim himself. Things are changing a little bit now with victims suing perpetrators and collecting and people who are convicted of crimes in some states have to make restitution to victims. so I thought I would just kind of carry that into a society that was not was less interested in punishing than in simply stopping the problem, whatever it was and since their system had no regular system for defense attorneys it seemed to me that it would naturally fall on the only people that were involved in the criminal legal system which would be the ones who are also working for the prosecutor. Actually, ideally, even in our culture, in a sense, the police should be working for the defendant because if they can remove any doubt that he's guilty, then when they take the case to court, why, it'll be a much sounder case. But it often happens that expedience gets in the way and pick someone who's likely and find all the evidence against them instead of sifting through all the evidence and then picking the only person who could possibly be the guilty party. Since you said that Doppelganger, Rama, and Deadly Silence are all in the same future history, can you give us an idea of the chronological order, maybe the distance, the time difference between those three books? and do you plan to write in this future history? I know you mentioned that you have a sidebar to Doppelganger Gambit. Do you plan to do a lot more writing in this future history? I think I will. It offers a lot of opportunities. There are any number of planets available to set stories on. and it cover a long span of time Doppelganger is the earliest because it's set right in the next century and then it's possible that voice out of Rama could come about at the same time as as Deadly Silence but probably not the ships that set out to take shuttle boxes to the various colonies and put them in contact with the rest of the universe again set out about the time the shuttle box was developed and got perfected so they had ships out running around and by the time one particular ship got to the planet, got to Mara why it may have been several hundred years even after Deadly Silence. But Deadly Silence and Voice Out of Rama are very close to each other, within a century or two of each other. Deadly Silence is five or six hundred years after A Voice Out of Rama. And, of course, the one I'm writing at the moment is within a century. of the doppelganger gambit. It's a little difficult figuring real time and the fact that they had time dilation going on their ship. So they were actually 10 years away from Earth when everything happened. So in actual real time, probably the book I'm writing now and the doppelganger gambit happen almost simultaneously. Your fourth novel, The Monitor of the Miners and the Shri is completely different. And as you said, it's in a different future history. Will you do any writing in that future history? Or what was it? The Sodality? That was the the governing organization. that's a future history that i was working on as a teenager and which started out as very peaceful and wonderful and tended to get much more complex and much more violent the older i got the more i realized that people just didn't get along with each other all the time i have several short stories that are said in that particular universe and i'll probably come back to it again it's an interesting one because it has a lot of different groups none of which are human and offers possibilities for societies and interplays. And aliens, the future history I have set up, the one that most of the novels are in, has a minimal of aliens the far we actually want to run across. One, which is spacing. And then, of course, there's the aliens that are on the planet on which the colonists who are in trouble on the Invictus lands, the book I'm working on at the moment, has some aliens on it. But there's a minimal of aliens, and if I want to deal with alien species, it's just really easy to go to that other future history which has all kinds of aliens running around. I like to think of it as just being across, being on our same galaxy, it's just on the other side, way out of contact with us, probably not where we're likely to run into it very soon. I'd like to ask you a question here, not so much as a science fiction writer, just from all your experience up to now. What is your idea of aliens, as far as real life is concerned? We have the idea that there are a lot of them. Other people have the idea that maybe life is abundant, but intelligence is not. Do you have any feelings about that one way or the other, predictions now. I just can't feel that we're the only intelligent species in the galaxy. In the universe. With infinite possibilities and infinite worlds out there, possibly less of them habitable by our standards than we might like to think because you have to have them within a continual life zone instead of these edges where they keep slipping in and out of a limestone. So maybe the possibilities for really intelligent life are fewer, but I think they're out there somewhere, and I would really love to meet one. This book strikes me as coming closest to a so-called hard science fiction book, and you evidently put in a lot of work on the biology and the evolutionary facts of the Sri. Is this something that you've been thinking about since you were a teenager? Or how did that evolve? I think it's kind of evolved. Because of my husband's interest in psychology and law, I started out and my interest was mostly in really hard science fiction. I was a die-hard analog reader. and the first story ever sold was to analog and it was an analog kind of story I haven't sold a story to analog since almost everything I've written since has come out in well the majority of it's come out fantasy and science fiction I've had one in Galileo and a couple in his magazine before it folded but I got more and more interested in people and realizing that hardware wasn't the thing that it was people and that people were interesting and what made them tick. And so the more I started researching that, the more I got interested in what makes societies click. And then when I started making up aliens and I started reading a lot of anthropology to figure out really how societies go together, the more I read, the more I researched, the more fascinated I got. I put together a background book before I ever start. the novel itself. It's an amount of work that I know some people find exhausting. They couldn't do it and still write. They have any energy left to write the book. But I enjoy it. I'm very systematic. I start out with a lot of visual images in my head. And with vague visual images, you have to have them developed to a very clear, you have to develop a very clear image and you have to find the words for them and get them translated into actual words out of pictures before you can get them down on paper so i do a background book and i do maps of the planet and i do drawings of the flora and fauna and biographies of the people and the more i read and read on climatology and planetology the more complex backgrounds get now it takes me It takes me about the same amount of time to put a background together, but it gets much more complicated. Now the finished background is almost as thick as the final manuscript on the book. I keep finding out how complex societies and ecologies are. There's no way, of course, I can really create one in detail. But I keep working at making them as logical and as realistic as I can. I keep discovering how much people are influenced by their cultures in very unconscious ways. And I strive to make an alien that is genuinely alien, but of course not so much that a human won't be interested in reading about them. But so that they will react in very alien ways, I work out the culture down to jokes they think are funny and what the musical instruments are and what toys their kids play with and maybe even what their plumbing looks like. So I have the whole society created in such detail in my own mind that the characters' actions will be influenced by their environment. And a lot of times I find conflicts in the story then growing out of that society, so they don't just sound like a plot that's been picked up and translated from mainstream Earth. There are things that happened then that could only have happened on that particular planet because of their particular attitudes, because of their particular environment and culture. The tape is rolling again. The monitor of the miners in the tree ends with a trial. I suppose this must be inevitable since you've been around a lawyer so long. In fact, the lawyer half wrote that particular chapter. He was telling me, oh, this character ought to say that, then you ought to bring up this point, then you ought to bring counter with that legal point And the whole chapter definitely got submitted to him for scrutiny as to procedure and logical thinking. So he's half the creator of that last chapter. Your book of short stories, Aventine, just came out. Could you compare writing a novel with writing short stories beyond the obvious sheer amount of time it takes to put the words down? Well, I think in a novel, you have so much more time to create a society and a world and to dwell on character, characterization. A short story tends to be one little piece, one particular scene, one particular incident. particularly with Aventine stories. It's a mood that's created. It's kind of a night gallery kind of mood, I think, probably. In a night gallery kind of visual image there. And the short story, of course, would be very concise. But I think dealing with a little punch, you know, boom, here's one idea. Yes, look it over and here it is. Whereas the novel, you deal with a lot of complex ideas and a long span of time. It isn't so much mood, perhaps, for a novel. It's definitely characterization, the creation of a whole lot of things around the characters. Sometimes when I read science fiction books, I get the idea that the writer is a frustrated scientist who can't, so he or she writes. When I read Aventine, I couldn't help but notice the centering on the arts in all their various guises. Are you a frustrated artist? Well, I don't think I'm frustrated. I am an artist. My artistry happens to be writing. i'm also a fair singer and i do a fair amount of drawing most of the drawing these days it becomes drawing for the background books that i put together that whole group centering around the arts was kind of an accident the first story of the group was the siren garden and then I did a second one that was Tropic of Eden and when that came out in the magazine the little blurb that went with it said something about the future of the arts so every time I turned in a story to him after that I'd simply written a story around one of the arts he sort of sent up a pattern with his little intro and I simply kept it up I had no objections to it because I find dancing fascinating. And I've been involved in theater. So I enjoy the arts very much and I'm very much a part of them. And I do consider myself an artist. Somebody said writers aren't born, artists are. And some artists are dancers, some artists are painters, and some of us are writers. Did you have to work hard to come up with some of the futuristic art forms such as the moving sculptures and the infrared detected dance, that sort of thing? most of that it's a little hard for me to remember how hard it was because once of course it's created it seems like it was inevitable that it happened that way most of those stories came out of of images there'd be like one single image I like the image of a pair of footprints, scarlet and sand, going away and the image just kept with me and kept with me, until I found a story to go with it. I can't remember if I had to work hard to get those futuristic art forms or not, I really can't. All but one of the stories, the Aventine stories in the collection, are written from a first person male point of view. Why did you write them from a male point of view, and is this kind of challenging since your background is the opposite sex? I'm not sure why I started writing them out from a male point of view. I can't remember for the genesis of the Siren Garden story. I can remember some of the elements that went into it. I think possibly it was because one of my favorite group of short stories has been J.G. Balares' Vermillion Sands story. They're very much the same kind of mood and the same kind of a decadent society. And those were all written from a first-person male viewpoint. And that may have influenced, because I had this living gem idea that I tried in several forms, and had always failed with. And then I tried applying the kind of formula for the stories that were in the J.P.G. Ballard series. and it seemed to work and so I just kept up with it. I think if I were to write the whole thing over again I would try to experiment a little more as I did with Benet Noir which I turned things around then and had the one the woman telling it. I like those particular stories from a first person point of view because Because you can understand, then, the storyteller is always victimized in some way in those particular stories. And you see inside of him, and you don't see things outside. You just see things entirely from his point of view. And while you may think he's dumb and getting trapped like that, you can see why he ends up being victimized. You mentioned a few minutes ago that you were intrigued by the creative process. When I read Shadow Dance, I recall that Christopher Lloyd, the protagonist, we kind of see the creative process for his choreographing the dance. Is that pretty much how you came up with this idea? Did his line of reasoning follow your line of reasoning? Good question. In the sense that having been a dancer, the bits and pieces of past dances he'd done came back to him and one of them fell into place for him to use then. someone who is a dancer might get a second level of pleasure out of that particular story because basically the plot line with the two women and then the men that they have destroyed and the man that is destroyed by them in the story follows Jerome Robbins' ballet The Cage, which is a very science fiction-ish kind of ballet. If you ever have a chance to see it, you ought to because it's really a very strange ballet. But I came across a scenario that explained that particular ballet, and then I happened to see it performed, and it seemed a great plot, generally, to put, to use for a story. So I used it in that particular story. and I think his creative process kind of follows the way that a lot of creative process does you have a lot of past experience and a lot of ideas floating around and then two good ones bump into each other and things click and then they start to add up Okay, what the engineer tells me we need Amen.

segments.text: Okay, the tape is on. Would you give us some biographical data on how you grew up and how
you got interested in writing science fiction.
Well, I grew up in Kansas. Both of my parents teach. At least my mother used to and then
she became a newspaper woman. So we, I grew up with words around the house, a lot. Oh,
I was making up stories from, well, I guess I was four or five,
the kind of thing where mother reads you the bedtime story and puts you to bed
and nobody feels like going to sleep yet.
So since I was too young to read,
I hadn't discovered reading on the covers with flashlights yet,
I made up stories until I was ready to go to sleep.
And then I started writing them down when I learned to write.
And about junior high school, I discovered science fiction.
Up to then, it was cowboys and horses, with a lot of girls, I think.
I discovered science fiction in junior high, and I don't know why it caught me the way it did.
I kind of got away from it later and got strictly into mystery,
and then came back to science fiction when I was in college.
and I've been hooked on science fiction mysteries ever since.
You probably noticed that a lot
of the combination of the two in my work.
Being a little Kansas girl
did you ever read the Oz books?
No, as a matter of fact
I think
aside from The Wizard of Oz
I think I'd only seen
I knew there were a number of others
because I had some friends that had others
but I'd never read them
and I still haven't read them.
The dedications to all five of the books that you have in print now
are all to Pat.
He must have influenced you a great deal.
Could you give some background into that influence
and how he helped you get where you are?
When we got married, I was writing.
We got married back in 66,
and I think that Star Trek was either on the air, I think it was on the air at the time,
and like a lot of people I got really hooked on Star Trek and was writing episodes for
it, and I guess at that time we were just going together.
At any rate, when we got married, I had stopped writing Star Trek and writing some stuff of
my own and he got ignored somewhat because I was busy writing and he said as long as
you are going to be doing that, why don't you try sending it out?
He bugged me, bugged me until I finally started sending things out and once I got sent sending
stuff out, of course I had lots of rejections.
he was very good about letting me cry on his shoulder and also very candid about his opinion
in on the various stories, some which led to grand battles, but he usually turned out
to be right.
So he was very influential in getting me writing and in getting me sending out and keeping
me sending out.
And then once the story started selling, and once I turned to novels, he was my critic
and chief cheerleader.
and I understand there are a lot of spouses
that writers don't like to consult with their spouses
very much because they're either too critical
or they're not critical enough.
But Pat is very objective
and he's an excellent critic
and he knows, he has a good feel for what is right
and what's wrong with a story.
And he has to hear everything I read
chapter by chapter and all the revisions
so he's very patient and long-suffering
and he puts up with being ignored evening after evening so that I can write
because I've got deadlines I have to meet.
He understands that.
He makes sure I don't kill myself.
Well, he comes in and pulls the plug on the typewriter at 2 or 3 in the morning
if I'm starting to pull an all-nighter to make sure I get to sleep
because I do have a job to get to the next morning.
So he's very important.
He's, as I say, a chief critic and cheerleader.
he's now also my business manager
he handles the publicity
he talks to the TV stations
to get the interviews on TV
to get autograph sessions set up
he handles plane tickets
and hotel reservations
and all the business ends
he's an attorney
so he's an expert on copyright
and he's starting to get seminars
on copyright
as a matter of fact
and he handles all the taxes
and all the business work
So, it's kind of a partnership.
I do the writing and get the publishing done.
And he does all the work that keeps it going.
According to the bios in the backs of some of the books,
it also says that Pat introduced you to science fiction fandom
and to science fiction conventions.
Do you find these a great help to your writing?
I've met a lot of writers at the science fiction conventions.
I've just been doing short stories.
and it was meeting the writers that got me started writing the novels
because they were the ones who were saying,
that's the only place you're going to make any money
or make any kind of name for yourself.
But short stories, you can't make any money in short stories.
And, of course, some of the writers have become some of my dearest friends now.
I really like talking about writing.
So I love meeting fans who want to do nothing more than sit up all night
and talk about science fiction and writing.
and I really think that it helps because you meet people,
and then you're a face to them, not just a name,
and they'll read something that is written by someone they know,
and then they can recommend it to friends,
and I realize that only a very small percentage of the population
is in fandom and attends a convention.
If all the fans in the United States bought a book, it would be a failure.
You have to have a lot more than that.
But still, I think it helps.
And you get used to talking to people and get used to going on TV shows.
Pretty soon, I'm going to make some trips to the East Coast this year,
and I hope soon to make some trips to the West Coast,
which means I'll get autograph sessions at bookstores out there,
which will get my name spread a little wider.
So aside from being a lot of fun, I think that as far as a writing career goes,
that going to the convention is very, it pays.
You also work full-time, as I understand it.
Would you describe what your real-world job is
and also how you schedule your writing and your job so you can get both done?
well the job is a regular 9 to 5 job as it happens I'm chief technologist in the department of
radiology at the college of veterinary medicine I'm an x-ray technician for animals in what it
amounts to I'm in charge of educating the vet students that is I'm in charge of them when
they're in the department itself which is sort of a laboratory situation for them and I think
It's a 9-to-5 job, and then I come home and write in the evening.
I usually end up taking a notebook with notes on whatever the current work is to work with me,
and there's a hiatus now and then.
And when that happens, I can sit down and jot notes.
I can't actually get any writing done.
I've got too much to do, and there isn't enough of a long span of no work to get anything done.
but a lot of times in the midst of purely physical activity
or purely routine activity at work,
something I've been having a problem with, for instance,
or an idea for a revision or an idea of something to do in the chapter ahead
will come up, and I can jot it down.
I'm still working while I'm in the real world job
because my subconscious is still grinding away
of whatever the writing project is at home,
And then I come home when I write in the evening and I'll write through on weekends, too.
How do your colleagues and students at work take to your writing?
What do they think about it?
They're very tickled about it.
I didn't know how administration and some of the doctors, the clinicians, would take
to it because science fiction in many quarters thought of as a very lowbrow kind of writing.
writing, but I find that they're very pleased about it when the dean of the vet school brings
people to our hospital on a tour.
He usually makes mention of the fact that I'm a public science fiction writer, and I've
gotten a couple of attaboy kind of letters from the president of the university.
And we have, of course, journalism students at the university, and I'm usually good for
for about one appearance in the paper per semester,
as one of the journalism students
has to get his so many inches of copy in,
and almost always one of them will appear.
I'm pretty well publicized around campus,
and I don't find them looking down on me
because I'm being published in fiction and science fiction
instead of in scientific journals,
like most of them get published.
So they take it very well and my boss is a real king.
I usually turn in my convention schedule to him at the beginning of summer.
He fits his vacations in between my convention schedule.
And he lets me off almost any weekend I want during the year to go to conventions too.
Our first exposure to you as a novelist was A Voice out of Rama.
And that book seemed to set the tone for some of your subsequent works with the various elements in it.
As you mentioned previously, it's got a bit of a mystery,
although not quite as much as some of the other novels.
How did you come to write this book?
How long did the idea sit there percolating before it came out?
I don't really know.
I try to keep track of the process of creativity because it fascinates me.
Also, because as a writer I'm asked so many questions about where ideas come from and how they develop that I keep trying to find out.
I had a couple of writers who ganged up on me at some conventions convincing me that I really needed to write a novel.
And I don't know, just these little bits and pieces just all came together.
I keep telling people that creativity is a little bit like recombinant DNA.
all the little
everything you read and see and hear
breaks up into component
parts and proves around
your subconscious until it reaches
a critical mass
that is also viable
and then it rises to the surface and you start
putting ideas
around it because the idea that comes up
is just the grain in the middle
you have to add all the rest of it around
but
I had tried to do some
Sherlock Holmes pastitions.
And one of them was a reverse,
where all the Holmes, Watson characters were females.
And I had half invented a planet that had a matriarchy.
So that got me started thinking about
how a matriarchy would work,
and why it would develop.
And so I found myself working back for causes like that,
And all of a sudden I had the society that I used then in Voice Out of Rama.
And once I had the society, I just kind of sat down and thought,
well, what kind of plot elements, what kind of conflicts can arise out of this society
that would probably not arise out of any other?
And who is the one that's going to be most affected by these?
And so I came up with the plot that way, and I came up with my major character that way.
After that, it was fun just building the planet
and trying to make it as realistic
and as logical as I could.
Then the doppelganger gamut came along,
and it seemed to be quite a change of pace
since it was basically a police procedure
science fiction novel.
You seem to be very familiar with police procedure,
with how partners have the interaction,
that sort of thing? Is this something from your background or did you have to research this?
I haven't had any practical experience in it. I did have a police officer come up to me at a
science fiction convention once when I'd been reading a chapter of Doppelganger.
And he asked me when I worked in law enforcement. But I've been interested in law enforcement for
a long time. I noticed that the mysteries I always liked to read were the ones in which
the police were the good guys. I was never particularly interested in the lone wolf private
eye. I got listened to Dragnet on the radio and saw it on TV when I was pretty small,
and I think maybe that's my first brush with police work, and I was just very interested
in it. Joseph Wambau is one of my favorite authors, and I happened to know somebody,
by the way, who gave him a copy of Doppelganger Gambit, and he told his friend that he really
liked it a lot, which tickled me. Once I decided I wanted to write a mystery science fiction,
I went ahead and did more research, and I've kept into it, and of course that book itself
and others have brought me into contact with more police officers, and they've passed on
a lot of material to me.
And so, short of actually working in it myself,
I have gotten very familiar with it.
I suppose I keep reading about it,
or writing about it,
because it was interesting
and because I've done so much research on it
that it's a shame not to use the material.
The key to that book for me
was the characters,
Jana Brill and Mama Maxwell.
Were they based on people you'd known before, or what?
No, they were based on nobody I know, except that I always pictured Mama Maxwell
as looking like Luke Ossett Jr., which I was very surprised, then, to get the cover proof
and find that the cover artist, Michael Herring, had also pictured him the same way
and found a model that looked so much like the character that I'd pictured.
It was wonderful.
Somewhere in the beginning when I was putting the book together,
which had started as a novelette, and I knew it couldn't be a novelette
because here I was 15 pages into something and just barely starting it,
I had decided I wanted to use a Lady Cop.
So for contrast, I gave her a male partner
and I can't remember why I decided to make him black
it was one of these things
that just kind of happened
somebody later pointed out that
I had
my female character was the one that was working
by the book and procedure and my male character
was the one who was working on intuition
which is an interesting reverse on
the way people generally think of males
and females
and that just sort of happened
the characters sort of balanced one another
but a lot of the balance was unconscious on my part
they were fun characters
and I intend to work with them again.
So we will see them again.
Oh, yes.
As soon as I can think of something more for them to get into.
One of the other things that I really noticed in the book
that made it that much more realistic was the slang.
I'm particularly curious where the term Leos came from,
a reference to the police officers.
I would think I was seeing something about law enforcement officers one time
and I noticed that it made Leo,
And I thought, that's great, because it gave rise in my mind to all kinds of connotations,
and I could see police officers enjoying being called Leos because of the lion,
the fierce kind of association you get with it, and therefore calling police stations lion den.
And someone who's likely to be picked up by the police is lion meat.
I had a pejorative
I had the street people calling them pussies
when they weren't happy with them
but my editor wouldn't let me keep the word in the book
so I think it got changed to kitty a couple of times in the book
and I illuminated it where possible
because I really didn't like watered down
I really did want to use pussy
because it seemed to me like the normal way
people would pick up and twist something
when they wanted to make a derogatory term out of it
I enjoy the slang.
I enjoy trying to figure out where slang comes from and where it's going to go.
And you may have noticed in a number of the books that I've played on slang,
there's quite a bit of it in Deadly Silence.
And I'm even having some alien slang in the current work I'm doing.
Deadly Silence seemed, I took, to be in the same future history as the doppelganger gambit.
They all are, as a matter of fact, except monitor. That was in a different one.
And there you went a little bit into the etymology of the word cop.
I didn't realize that's where it came from until I read it in that book.
There are several possibilities.
They usually teach a little bit of that in police history.
When they're teaching in police academies,
One thought it meant constable on patrol, and sometimes it said, well, it comes from the copper buttons that they used to wear.
And the exact origin of the word isn't known.
But it's interesting to me to stumble across the term conservator of peace way back in early England.
And it seems to me that an alien who was reading Earth's history
and having come across the word cop, referring to police officers, and the earlier conservative of peace,
conservator of peace, might connect the two.
I found it interesting that the duties of the cops,
you did call them cops from then on, from chapter 2 or whatever,
for the rest of the book, because of the connotations of Leos.
I found it interesting that their first priority was to the victim,
and then, lo and behold, later on, they have to defend the perpetrator.
Where did you come up with these seemingly novel ideas?
They kind of grew out of the society of the Aragara
because the primary objective of the police there was,
of course, to restore peace, to be peace officers.
and of course when anything happened that was distressful to the Aragara it
was painful to everybody around them.
So the first duty then was to the victim to help them understand what had happened to them.
I suppose it reflects a little bit of a reaction to some of the things that I've seen in our own culture
where the victim suffers a lot because everybody's so interested in catching the guy who did it
a lot of times they're not paying too much attention to the victim himself.
Things are changing a little bit now with victims suing perpetrators and collecting
and people who are convicted of crimes in some states have to make restitution to victims.
so I thought I would just
kind of carry that into a society
that was not
was less interested
in punishing than in
simply stopping
the problem, whatever it was
and
since their system had no
regular system for defense attorneys
it seemed to me that it would
naturally fall on the only people
that were involved in the criminal
legal system which would be
the ones who are also working for the prosecutor.
Actually, ideally, even in our culture,
in a sense, the police should be working for the defendant
because if they can remove any doubt that he's guilty,
then when they take the case to court,
why, it'll be a much sounder case.
But it often happens that expedience gets in the way
and pick someone who's likely and find all the evidence against them
instead of sifting through all the evidence
and then picking the only person who could possibly be the guilty party.

I think I will.
It offers a lot of opportunities.
There are any number of planets available

and
it cover a long span of time
Doppelganger
is the earliest

and then
it's
possible
that voice out of

could come about at the same time as

set out about the time the shuttle box was developed

so they had ships out running around

why it may have been several hundred years even after Deadly Silence.
But Deadly Silence and Voice Out of Rama are very close to each other,
within a century or two of each other.
Deadly Silence is five or six hundred years after A Voice Out of Rama.
And, of course, the one I'm writing at the moment is within a century.
of the doppelganger gambit.
It's a little difficult figuring real time

going on their ship.
So they were actually 10 years away from Earth

So in actual real time,
probably the book I'm writing now
and the doppelganger gambit
happen almost simultaneously.
Your fourth novel,
The Monitor of the Miners and the Shri
is completely different.
And as you said, it's in a different
future history.
Will you do any writing in that future history?
Or what was it? The Sodality? That was the
the governing organization.
that's a future history that i was working on as a teenager and which started out as very peaceful
and wonderful and tended to get much more complex and much more violent the older i got the more i
realized that people just didn't get along with each other all the time i have several short
stories that are said in that particular universe and i'll probably come back to it again it's an
interesting one because it has a lot of different groups none of which are human
and offers possibilities for societies and interplays.
And aliens, the future history I have set up,
the one that most of the novels are in,
has a minimal of aliens the far we actually want to run across.
One, which is spacing.
And then, of course, there's the aliens that are on the planet
on which the colonists who are in trouble on the Invictus lands,
the book I'm working on at the moment, has some aliens on it.
But there's a minimal of aliens, and if I want to deal with alien species,
it's just really easy to go to that other future history
which has all kinds of aliens running around.
I like to think of it as just being across, being on our same galaxy,
it's just on the other side, way out of contact with us,
probably not where we're likely to run into it very soon.
I'd like to ask you a question here,
not so much as a science fiction writer,
just from all your experience up to now.
What is your idea of aliens, as far as real life is concerned?
We have the idea that there are a lot of them.
Other people have the idea that maybe life is abundant,
but intelligence is not.
Do you have any feelings about that one way or the other,
predictions now.
I just can't feel that we're the only
intelligent species in the
galaxy.
In the universe.
With infinite possibilities and infinite
worlds out there,
possibly less
of them habitable by our
standards than we might like
to think because you have to have them within a
continual life zone instead of
these edges where they keep slipping in and out of a limestone.
So maybe the possibilities for really intelligent life are fewer,
but I think they're out there somewhere,
and I would really love to meet one.
This book strikes me as coming closest to a so-called hard science fiction book,
and you evidently put in a lot of work on the biology
and the evolutionary facts of the Sri.
Is this something that you've been thinking about
since you were a teenager?
Or how did that evolve?
I think it's kind of evolved.
Because of my husband's interest in psychology and law,
I started out and my interest was mostly
in really hard science fiction.
I was a die-hard analog reader.
and the first story ever sold was to analog and it was an analog kind of story
I haven't sold a story to analog since almost everything I've written since has come out in
well the majority of it's come out fantasy and science fiction I've had
one in Galileo and a couple in his magazine before it folded
but I got more and more interested in people and realizing that hardware wasn't the thing
that it was people and that people were interesting and what made them tick.
And so the more I started researching that, the more I got interested in what makes societies click.
And then when I started making up aliens and I started reading a lot of anthropology
to figure out really how societies go together, the more I read, the more I researched,
the more fascinated I got.
I put together a background book before I ever start.
the novel itself. It's an amount of work that I know some people find exhausting. They couldn't
do it and still write. They have any energy left to write the book. But I enjoy it. I'm
very systematic. I start out with a lot of visual images in my head. And with vague visual
images, you have to have them developed to a very clear, you have to develop a very clear
image and you have to find the words for them and get them translated into actual words out of
pictures before you can get them down on paper so i do a background book and i do maps of the planet
and i do drawings of the flora and fauna and biographies of the people and the more i read
and read on climatology and planetology the more complex backgrounds get now it takes me
It takes me about the same amount of time to put a background
together, but it gets much more complicated. Now the finished
background is almost as thick as the final manuscript on the book.
I keep finding out how complex societies and ecologies are.
There's no way, of course, I can really create one in detail.
But I keep working at making them as logical
and as realistic as I can.
I keep discovering how much people are influenced by their cultures
in very unconscious ways.
And I strive to make an alien that is genuinely alien,
but of course not so much that a human won't be interested in reading about them.
But so that they will react in very alien ways,
I work out the culture down to jokes they think are funny
and what the musical instruments are
and what toys their kids play with
and maybe even what their plumbing looks like.
So I have the whole society created in such detail in my own mind
that the characters' actions will be influenced by their environment.
And a lot of times I find conflicts in the story then growing out of that society,
so they don't just sound like a plot that's been picked up and translated from mainstream Earth.
There are things that happened then that could only have happened on that particular planet
because of their particular attitudes, because of their particular environment and culture.
The tape is rolling again.
The monitor of the miners in the tree ends with a trial.
I suppose this must be inevitable since you've been around a lawyer so long.
In fact, the lawyer half wrote that particular chapter.
He was telling me, oh, this character ought to say that,
then you ought to bring up this point,
then you ought to bring counter with that legal point
And the whole chapter definitely got submitted to him for scrutiny
as to procedure and logical thinking.
So he's half the creator of that last chapter.
Your book of short stories, Aventine, just came out.
Could you compare writing a novel with writing short stories
beyond the obvious sheer amount of time it takes to put the words down?
Well, I think in a novel, you have so much more time to create a society and a world
and to dwell on character, characterization.
A short story tends to be one little piece, one particular scene, one particular incident.
particularly with Aventine stories.
It's a mood that's created.
It's kind of a night gallery kind of mood, I think, probably.
In a night gallery kind of visual image there.
And the short story, of course, would be very concise.
But I think dealing with a little punch, you know,
boom, here's one idea.
Yes, look it over and here it is.
Whereas the novel, you deal with a lot of complex ideas
and a long span of time.
It isn't so much mood, perhaps, for a novel.
It's definitely characterization,
the creation of a whole lot of things around the characters.
Sometimes when I read science fiction books, I get the idea that the writer is a frustrated scientist who can't,
so he or she writes. When I read Aventine, I couldn't help but notice the centering on the arts in all their various guises.
Are you a frustrated artist?
Well, I don't think I'm frustrated. I am an artist. My artistry happens to be writing.
i'm also a fair singer and i do a fair amount of drawing most of the drawing these days it
becomes drawing for the background books that i put together that whole group centering around
the arts was kind of an accident the first story of the group was the siren garden
and then I did a second one
that was
Tropic of Eden
and when that came out in the magazine
the little blurb that went with it
said something about the future of the arts
so every time I turned in a story
to him after that
I'd simply written a story
around one of the arts
he sort of sent up
a pattern with his little intro
and I simply kept it up
I had no objections to it because I find dancing fascinating.
And I've been involved in theater.
So I enjoy the arts very much and I'm very much a part of them.
And I do consider myself an artist.
Somebody said writers aren't born, artists are.
And some artists are dancers, some artists are painters,
and some of us are writers.

most of that
it's a little hard for me to remember
how hard it was
because once of course it's created
it seems like it was inevitable
that it happened that way
most of those stories
came out of
of images
there'd be like one single image
I like the image of a pair of footprints, scarlet and sand, going away and the image

And those were all written from a first-person male viewpoint.

And then I tried applying the kind of formula for the stories that were in the J.P.G. Ballard series.
and it seemed to work
and so I just kept up with it.
I think if I were

as I did with

the one
the woman
telling it.
I like those particular
stories from a first person
point of view because
Because you can understand, then, the storyteller is always victimized in some way in those particular stories.
And you see inside of him, and you don't see things outside.
You just see things entirely from his point of view.
And while you may think he's dumb and getting trapped like that, you can see why he ends up being victimized.
